articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Insurer Sells Lease Unit
articles.snippet: Fondiaria-SAI, Italian insurer, will sell its Mercantile Leasing unit to Banca Italease for 121 million euros ($146 million) (S)
articles.abstract: Fondiaria-SAI, Italian insurer, will sell its Mercantile Leasing unit to Banca Italease for 121 million euros ($146 million) (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Italy's largest property and casualty insurer, Fondiaria-SAI, agreed to sell its Mercantile Leasing unit to Banca Italease for 121 million euros ($146 million) as it sought to reorganize. Fondiaria-SAI will earn about 36 million euros from the sale, the insurer said.

articles.headline: The Resurgent Profitability of 2 Big Investment Banks
articles.snippet: Market Place column on resurgent profitability of investment banks Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs; each reportedly nears tentative accord with Securities and Exchange Commission to pay $40 million to settle charges growing out of last stock mark...
articles.abstract: Market Place column on resurgent profitability of investment banks Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs; each reportedly nears tentative accord with Securities and Exchange Commission to pay $40 million to settle charges growing out of last stock market bubble; Goldman reports second-quarter earnings rose 71 percent from 2003 period, to $1.2 billion; Morgan Stanley reports earnings jumped 104 percent from 2003 quarter, also to $1.2 billion; both warn continued stock market weakness could hurt future earnings (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs reported sharp increases in their second-quarter earnings yesterday, propelled by a surge in investment banking business and robust trading profits.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Sex-Bias Suit Given Class-Action Status
articles.snippet: Federal Judge Martin J Jenkins rules in San Francisco that lawsuit charging Wal-Mart Stores with discriminating against women can proceed as class action covering about 1.6 million current and former employees, making it largest workplace-bias cas...
articles.abstract: Federal Judge Martin J Jenkins rules in San Francisco that lawsuit charging Wal-Mart Stores with discriminating against women can proceed as class action covering about 1.6 million current and former employees, making it largest workplace-bias case in US history; lawsuit brought by six women accuses company of systematically paying women less than men and offering fewer promotions, citing fact that women make up 65 percent of hourly workers but only 33 percent of managers; Wal-Mart to appeal certification, saying company does not discriminate and that wage and promotion decisions are made by individual stores; huge discounter, worried about angry shoppers, has spent millions of dollars on ads showcasing treatment of women and plans to increase wages and improve workplace practices; Brad Seligman of Impact Fund, lead counsel for plaintiffs, says fundamental change at Wal-Mart would help all workers (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Constance L. Hays

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Airline Gets Help
articles.snippet: Italian government says it will guarantee short-term loan for Alitalia to give national airline money needed to begin restructuring plan; loan will reportedly be about 400 million euros ($484.6 million) (S)
articles.abstract: Italian government says it will guarantee short-term loan for Alitalia to give national airline money needed to begin restructuring plan; loan will reportedly be about 400 million euros ($484.6 million) (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Italian government said it would guarantee a short-term loan for Alitalia so the country's national airline would have the money to pull itself through a financial crisis that pushed the company to the brink of bankruptcy. Alitalia and the government would not give further details, but according to a person close to the airline who did not want to be identified, the loan will be for about 400 million euros ($484.6 million). The loan will give Alitalia, which lost 511 million euros last year, the money it needs to begin a restructuring plan that management says will return the airline to profitability in two years. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

articles.headline: Suing Wal-Mart but Still Hoping to Move Up
articles.snippet: Betty Dukes, lead plaintiff in suit charging Wal-Mart with widespread discrimination against women workers, comments on suit and her determination to move up at company; Wal-Mart says it is continuing to review its employment practices; table and ...
articles.abstract: Betty Dukes, lead plaintiff in suit charging Wal-Mart with widespread discrimination against women workers, comments on suit and her determination to move up at company; Wal-Mart says it is continuing to review its employment practices; table and graph of job-discrimination cases; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The way Betty Dukes tells it, it is not for lack of trying that she has failed to move up at Wal-Mart Stores. Despite repeatedly asking her managers how she could advance, she says, the jobs she wanted were filled by men time and time again.

articles.headline: ELECTRONIC CARDS REPLACE COUPONS FOR FOOD STAMPS
articles.snippet: Bush administration completes conversion of food stamp program from paper coupons to electronic debit cards; invites public to suggest new name for program; Sec Ann M Veneman explains changes; photo; more than 23 million people receive food stamp ...
articles.abstract: Bush administration completes conversion of food stamp program from paper coupons to electronic debit cards; invites public to suggest new name for program; Sec Ann M Veneman explains changes; photo; more than 23 million people receive food stamp benefits, but only three out of five eligible people are participating (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration announced Tuesday that it had completed one of the biggest changes in the history of the food stamp program, replacing paper coupons with electronic benefits and debit cards.

articles.headline: Europe Looks More Closely at Plan for Uranium Venture
articles.snippet: European Commission's competition division ramps up its inquiry into planned joint venture between Areva and Urenco in which Areva would buy half of Urenco's uranium enrichment research division, Enrichment Technology Co; cites concern that deal m...
articles.abstract: European Commission's competition division ramps up its inquiry into planned joint venture between Areva and Urenco in which Areva would buy half of Urenco's uranium enrichment research division, Enrichment Technology Co; cites concern that deal might result in rise in price of enriched uranium used to fuel nuclear power stations and slow uranium enrichment research and development; two companies together have 80 percent of European Union enriched uranium sales; France's complaint on deal that would bolster French government-controlled Areva struck some as odd; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Commission's competition division ramped up its investigation Tuesday into a planned joint venture between Areva, the nuclear power company controlled by the French government, and its counterpart Urenco, which is owned by energy companies in Germany, Holland and Britain. The new investigation is expected to last four months.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Yellow Pages Offer
articles.snippet: France Telecom begins initial public offering of its directory unit PagesJaunes, aiming to sell 30 to 43 percent of company (S)
articles.abstract: France Telecom begins initial public offering of its directory unit PagesJaunes, aiming to sell 30 to 43 percent of company (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: France Télécom began an initial public offering of its directory unit PagesJaunes, aiming to sell 30 to 43 percent of the company. The sale will contribute to financing the group's buyout of its Internet subsidiary Wanadoo. Shares of PagesJaunes are offered from 13.2 to 15.2 euros ($16 to $18.40) for institutional investors. The offering will be opened to private investors in a price range of 12.9 to 14.9 euros a share. The offering should end on July 6, and trading should begin on July 7, France Télécom said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

articles.headline: 4 Rivals Near Agreement on Ways to Fight Spam
articles.snippet: America Online, Earthlink and Microsoft, which have merged their technical standards for identifying and discarding e-mail messages with fake return addresses, near accord with Yahoo, which develops more technically powerful approach to fighting s...
articles.abstract: America Online, Earthlink and Microsoft, which have merged their technical standards for identifying and discarding e-mail messages with fake return addresses, near accord with Yahoo, which develops more technically powerful approach to fighting spam, to give limited support to each other's technology; proponents say two approaches could be complementary; drawings (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Four large Internet service providers agreed yesterday to a partial truce in their battle with one another over potential technology to stop junk e-mail in hopes that they can devote their united energy to fighting spam.

articles.headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart Bias Lawsuit Proceeds as Class Action  A federal judge ruled that a lawsuit accusing Wal-Mart of discriminating against women can proceed as a class action covering about 1.6 million current and former employees, making it by far the larg...
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart Bias Lawsuit Proceeds as Class Action  A federal judge ruled that a lawsuit accusing Wal-Mart of discriminating against women can proceed as a class action covering about 1.6 million current and former employees, making it by far the largest workplace bias lawsuit in United States history.      The suit, bought by six women in 2001, accuses Wal-Mart of paying women less than men and offering fewer opportunities for promotion. Wal-Mart said it would appeal the class-action certification, arguing that it did not discriminate and that decisions about raises and promotion were made by individual stores, not on the corporate level. [Page A1.]
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Bias Lawsuit Proceeds as Class Action

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidences Rises
articles.snippet: ZEW Center for European Economic Research survey finds German investor confidence in economy rose slightly in June (S)
articles.abstract: ZEW Center for European Economic Research survey finds German investor confidence in economy rose slightly in June (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: German investor confidence rose slightly in June, according to a survey released by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research. The institute's index, which measures expectations for economic growth, rose for the first time in six months, to 47.4 in June, after dropping to 46.4 points in May. The center expressed disappointment about the June outcome. ''While it is good news that the downward trend in the economic sentiment has stopped for the present, hopes of a marked pickup have not been fulfilled, though some fundamental data point to an economic recovery,'' the center said in a statement. Victor Homola (NYT)

articles.headline: United Submits Third Request For Assistance To Loan Board
articles.snippet: United Submits Third Request For Assistance To Loan Board** United Airlines submits third bid to Air Transportation Stabilization Board, reportedly cutting request for federal loan guarantee to help it emerge from bankruptcy to $1.1 billion from $...
articles.abstract: United Submits Third Request For Assistance To Loan Board** United Airlines submits third bid to Air Transportation Stabilization Board, reportedly cutting request for federal loan guarantee to help it emerge from bankruptcy to $1.1 billion from $1.6 billion; pledges to find $500 million from lender not protected by guarantee and keep $1.5 billion in cash on hand during term of loan, which it offers to cut to five years; Treasury Sec John W Snow rejects offer by Under Sec Brian C Roseboro, one of two board members who voted against United's previous bid, to resign from board (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Five days after its last bid was rejected, United Airlines filed a revised application with a federal loan board yesterday, its third attempt to win assistance that would help it emerge from bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Senate Votes To Restore Media Limits
articles.snippet: Senate votes to repeal Federal Communications Commission rules changes that make it easier for largest media conglomerates to expand and enter new markets; seeks to restore rules that barred one company from owning both newspaper and television or...
articles.abstract: Senate votes to repeal Federal Communications Commission rules changes that make it easier for largest media conglomerates to expand and enter new markets; seeks to restore rules that barred one company from owning both newspaper and television or radio station in same city in most markets and repeal change that would let company own as many as three television stations, eight radio stations and cable operator in largest markets; appeals court has already temporarily blocked implementation of changes; Bush administration and Republican leaders in House opposed similar measure earlier this year; Sen Byron Dorgan, who co-sponsors bill with Sen Olympia J Snowe, comments, interview; Senate, 99-1, approves Sen Sam Brownback's bill to sharply raise penalties for broadcasters that violate federal decency standards; approves by voice vote Sen Ernest F Hollings's bill to direct FCC to study effectiveness of V-chip in controlling how much violence children watch on television and to ban violent programming during hours children most watch television if study finds chip is not effective; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted on Tuesday to repeal rules adopted by the Federal Communications Commission that make it easier for the nation's largest media conglomerates to expand and enter new markets.

articles.headline: Revised Report Finds Increase in Terrorism
articles.snippet: Article on State Department report concerning terrorism incidents in 2003 noted
articles.abstract: Article on State Department report concerning terrorism incidents in 2003 noted
articles.lead_paragraph: The State Department said the number of significant international terrorism episodes rose last year, contradicting an early report of a downward trend. The White House had cited that report as evidence it was winning its fight against terrorism, but disowned it after finding it was based on erroneous statistics.

articles.headline: A Politician Looking for Funds? Here Are Two Useful Addresses
articles.snippet: Computer analysis of contributions to presidential campaigns through April shows that two addresses, office building in downtown Los Angeles and San Remo apartment house on Manhattan's Upper West Side, are sources of more donations to Pres Bush an...
articles.abstract: Computer analysis of contributions to presidential campaigns through April shows that two addresses, office building in downtown Los Angeles and San Remo apartment house on Manhattan's Upper West Side, are sources of more donations to Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry, respectively, than any other single addresses in US; Los Angeles building houses Trust Company of the West, whose executives Robert A Day and Marc I Stern gave most of $297,000 from that address; San Remo is home to Democrats who gave almost $192,000 to Kerry; Kerry raised $7.7 million in Manhattan, $2.4 million in 10021 ZIP code on Upper East Side; Bush raised $7.4 million in Manhattan, $1.9 million in same ZIP code; photos; maps pinpointing contributions from areas of Manhattan, Los Angeles and Washington, DC (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The office building at 865 South Figueroa in downtown Los Angeles is a fairly typical high-rise, but inside the plain reddish-brown tower is the headquarters of an investment management company that handles roughly $90 billion in assets.

articles.headline: Molson Says It Might Sell Stake in Brazilian Unit
articles.snippet: Molson Cos chief executive Daniel J O'Neill says company may seek buyer for its 80 percent stake in Brazilian brewer Cervejarias Kaiser unless Kaiser's fortunes improve markedly by January, news conference after Molson annual meeting; deputy chair...
articles.abstract: Molson Cos chief executive Daniel J O'Neill says company may seek buyer for its 80 percent stake in Brazilian brewer Cervejarias Kaiser unless Kaiser's fortunes improve markedly by January, news conference after Molson annual meeting; deputy chairman R Ian Molson steps down from board after clashing with his distant cousin, chairman Eric H Molson; Ian's brother William, speaking at meeting, questions why Eric Molson, 66, has not supported Ian to succeed him; company cuts board to 10 directors from 15; Daniel W Colson is elected to board without support of several big outside shareholders; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Molson Companies, Canada's biggest brewer, may seek a buyer for its 80 percent stake in the Brazilian brewer Cervejarias Kaiser unless Kaiser's fortunes improve markedly by January, Molson's chief executive, Daniel J. O'Neill, said at the company's annual meeting on Tuesday.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Warns Loss Possible
articles.snippet: Swiss International Air Lines shares fall 5.3 percent to six-week low after carrier says it might post operating loss this year because of sharp rise in fuel prices; stock price graph (S)
articles.abstract: Swiss International Air Lines shares fall 5.3 percent to six-week low after carrier says it might post operating loss this year because of sharp rise in fuel prices; stock price graph (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of Swiss International Air Lines fell 5.3 percent to a six-week low after the carrier said that it might post an operating loss this year because of a sharp increase in fuel prices. Fuel prices might increase costs by 85 million Swiss francs ($68 million), the carrier said. Swiss International has had losses of more than 1.3 billion Swiss francs since it was created in a government-led bailout in March 2002. It has cut 3,000 jobs since the start of 2003 to reduce costs and cut fares to attract more travelers.

articles.headline: 10 Million Women Who Lack a Cervix Still Get Pap Tests
articles.snippet: Study finds that as many as ten million women who have had hysterectomies and no longer have cervix are still getting Pap tests for precancerous cells; Dr Brenda E Sirovich, lead author, says such testing makes no sense, leads to false positives a...
articles.abstract: Study finds that as many as ten million women who have had hysterectomies and no longer have cervix are still getting Pap tests for precancerous cells; Dr Brenda E Sirovich, lead author, says such testing makes no sense, leads to false positives and wastes money; women in question, about 12 percent of 85 million women being screened, are those who had surgery for noncancerous reasons; Sirovich cites doctors' habits and patients' expectations; report points out that no screening guidelines recommend Pap tests for most women without cervix (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: As many as 10 million women who have had hysterectomies and who no longer have a cervix are still getting Pap tests, a new study finds.

articles.headline: France Steps Up Its Investments in Iran
articles.snippet: French companies have been increasing their presence in Iran in last few years despite Iran's pariah status in United States and shortcomings of Iran's commercial climate; photos (M)
articles.abstract: French companies have been increasing their presence in Iran in last few years despite Iran's pariah status in United States and shortcomings of Iran's commercial climate; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Undeterred by Iran's pariah status in the United States and by the shortcomings of the country's commercial climate, French companies have been increasing their presence in the country in the last few years.

articles.headline: WHITE HOUSE SAYS PRISONER POLICY SET HUMANE TONE
articles.snippet: Pres Bush, in Feb 2002 directive on Afghanistan prisoners, broadly cited need for 'new thinking in the law of war,' while ordering humane treatment of all detainees in fight against terrorism, even if US does not consider them protected by Geneva ...
articles.abstract: Pres Bush, in Feb 2002 directive on Afghanistan prisoners, broadly cited need for 'new thinking in the law of war,' while ordering humane treatment of all detainees in fight against terrorism, even if US does not consider them protected by Geneva Conventions; statement of principle, now released, came in midst of intense administration debate on how far military and intelligence agencies could go in using coercive interrogation;  documents show Sec Donald Rumsfeld later approved techniques such as use of dogs, changes in diet and sleep cycles and isolation; White House counsel Alberto Gonzales says Bush never considered more aggressive options set out by administration lawyers; Justice Department says memo with permissive definition of torture is now being rewritten; Gonzales rejects any link between newly released documents and torture of Iraqis at Abu Ghraib prison (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: In a February 2002 directive that set new rules for handling prisoners captured in Afghanistan, President Bush broadly cited the need for ''new thinking in the law of war.'' He ordered that all people detained as part of the fight against terrorism should be treated humanely even if the United States considered them not to be protected by the Geneva Conventions, the White House said Tuesday.

articles.headline: South Korean Is Killed in Iraq By His Captors
articles.snippet: Kim Sun Il, South Korean interpreter who dreamed of becoming Christian missionary in Arab world, is beheaded by Iraqi insurgents who abducted him in Falluja five days ago; execution is carried out after South Korea rejects demand to halt deploymen...
articles.abstract: Kim Sun Il, South Korean interpreter who dreamed of becoming Christian missionary in Arab world, is beheaded by Iraqi insurgents who abducted him in Falluja five days ago; execution is carried out after South Korea rejects demand to halt deployment of 3,000 more troops; Al Jazeera videotape shows victim kneeling before five masked men believed linked to terrorist Abu Musab al-Zarquawi; photos; US airstrike hours later aims at Zarqawi safe house in Falluja, reportedly killing four people; Pres Bush says beheading is another futile effort to drive US out; Kim's body is found later; one of two major pipelines begins flowing with oil again, repaired after explosions; oil workers suspected in precise sabotage; huge new explosion rips pipeline to key Baghdad refinery; two US soldiers killed in Balad; Mosul University law school dean and wife are shot and killed and two Iraqis die in car bombing in Baghdad (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: A South Korean interpreter who dreamed of becoming a Christian missionary in the Arab world was beheaded Tuesday by the insurgents who held him captive after his abduction five days ago near Falluja.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and James Glanz

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Book Seller Suspends Talks
articles.snippet: W H Smith, British newsstand operator, suspends takeover talks with Permira Advisers, which it says is highly unlikely to offer 371 pence ($6.75) a share; says it is in talks with number of parties to sell its Hodder Headline publishing business (...
articles.abstract: W H Smith, British newsstand operator, suspends takeover talks with Permira Advisers, which it says is highly unlikely to offer 371 pence ($6.75) a share; says it is in talks with number of parties to sell its Hodder Headline publishing business (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: W.H. Smith, the British newsstand operator, suspended takeover talks with Permira Advisers, a buyout firm, because Permira was deterred by the magazine and book retailer's pension deficit. Permira is ''highly unlikely'' to offer 371 pence ($6.75) a share for the company, W.H. Smith said. The retailer also said it was in talks ''with a number of parties'' to sell its Hodder Headline publishing business to return cash to shareholders.
